places.name: Vauxhall Gardens
places.description: A pleasure garden in London in the late eighteenth and nineteenth century. Davy wrote a poem titled 'Vauxhall'.

persons.name: AnnaBeddoes
persons.description: Anna Beddoes, née Edgeworth, the wife of Thomas Beddoes who befriended Davy when he arrived in Bristol. Critics have speculated that they had an affair because Davy wrote poems to Anna and she wrote poems for him that he copied out in his notebooks.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

persons.name: PierreGassendi
persons.description: French philosopher, Catholic priest, astronomer and mathematician who published the first data on the transit of Mercury in 1631.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: GalileoGalilei
persons.description: Italian astronomer, physicist, and engineer.

persons.name: Christlieb EhregottGellert
persons.description: German metallurgist and mineralogist. Author of introductory works on metallurgy.

persons.name: GeorgiusAgricola
persons.description: Physician who studied the minerals and mining practices in Saxony and surrounding areas. His influential book De re metallica (1556) was published postumously.

persons.name: CharlesDilly
persons.description: English publisher and bookseller

persons.name: JędrzejŚniadecki
persons.description: Possibly: Jędrzej Śniadecki a Polish writer, physician, chemist, biologist and philosopher. His achievements include being the first person who linked rickets to lack of sunlight. He also created modern Polish terminology in the field of chemistry.

works.name: Of the Proficience and Advancement of Learning, Divine and Human
works.author: Francis Bacon

persons.name: Archimedes
persons.description: Ancient Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, astronomer and inventor from Syracuse in Sicily.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: WilliamBabington
persons.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamWavell
persons.description: Brought a mineral to the attention of minerologists in 1805 that was named in his honour: Wavellite.

places.name: Devon
places.description: A county in south-west England.

persons.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamBabington
persons.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamBabington
persons.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

persons.name: RichardStocker
persons.description: Resident apothecary at Guy's Hospital in London and an early member of the Mineralogical Society, which was founded in 1799 with the object of carrying out chemical analyses of mineral samples.

persons.name: WilliamBabington
persons.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
persons.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

persons.name: JohnBrown
persons.description: Scottish physician who argued that all diseases were a result of too much or too little excitability in the body.

persons.name: Sanzio da UrbinoRaphael
persons.description: Italian Renaissance painter and architect

persons.name: Alonso BarbaAlvaro
persons.description: a secular Catholic priest and metallurgist born in Lepe , a town in the province of Seville, in Andalusia, Spain. He published Arte de los Metales [Art of metals] in Madrid in 1640 and this book was translated into English by Edward Montagu in 1670.

persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

places.name: Athens
places.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

persons.name: ZoeKing
persons.description: The daughter of John King, who worked with Davy and Beddoes in the Medical Pneumatic Institute and Emmeline Edgeworth, sister of Maria. Davy wrote poetry addressed to Zoe when she was a child.

places.name: London
places.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

persons.name: JosiahWedgwood
persons.description: Renowned British potter whose factory was at Etruria near Stoke-on-Trent. A strong supporter of the abolition of the slave trade and of slavery, he was closely connected with other industrialists in the Midlands. FRSL.

persons.name: René JustHaüy
persons.description: French priest, crystallographer and mineralogist who wrote the five volume Traité de minéralogie (1801). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: GeorgiusAgricola
persons.description: Physician who studied the minerals and mining practices in Saxony and surrounding areas. His influential book De re metallica (1556) was published postumously.

works.name: Sur La Philosophie Minéralogique, et Sur L'Espèce Minéralogique
works.author: Déodat Gratet de Dolomieu

persons.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
persons.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

persons.name: NehemiahGrew
persons.description: English plant anatomist and physiologist, known as the 'Father of Plant Anatomy'. FRSL.

persons.name: Porphyry
persons.description: A Neoplatonic philosopher born in Tyre, Roman Phoenicia during Roman rule.

persons.name: Hesiod
persons.description: An ancient Greek poet generally thought to have been active between 750 and 650 BC, around the same time as Homer. In c. 730–700 BC. he wrote a poem, called the Theogony, describing the origins and genealogies of the Greek gods.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

places.name: Arkendale
places.description: a village and civil parish in the Harrogate district of North Yorkshire, England

places.name: River Tees
places.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.

places.name: Northumberland
places.description: County in the North East of England. It borders Scotland to the north and the county of Cumbria to the west.

places.name: Derbyshire
places.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

places.name: Yorkshire
places.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

places.name: Alston Moor
places.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

persons.description: Proprietor of the Royal Institution and involved with the Board of Agriculture

places.description: Cumberland is a historic county in the far north-west of England.

places.name: Nenthead
places.description: a major centre for lead and silver mining in the North Pennines of Britain. The first smelt mill was built at Nenthead in 1737.

places.name: Durham, England
places.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.

places.name: Yorkshire
places.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

places.name: Alston Moor
places.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

places.name: Dufton
places.description: a village and civil parish in Cumbria, England. Historically part of Westmorland, it lies in the Eden Valley and below Great Dun Fell. It was a centre for lead mining in the 18th and 19th centuries.

places.name: Teesdale
places.description: Teesdale is a dale, or valley, in northern England.

places.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

places.name: River Tees
places.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.

places.name: Egglestone Hall
places.description: William Hutchinson (1763-1826) built Eggleston Hall in Teesdale County Durham in about 1817

places.name: High Force
places.description: High Force is a waterfall on the River Tees, near Middleton-in-Teesdale, Teesdale, England.

places.name: High Force
places.description: High Force is a waterfall on the River Tees, near Middleton-in-Teesdale, Teesdale, England.

places.name: Winch Bridge
places.description: Wynch Bridge or Winch Bridge is a suspension bridge on the River Tees. The original Wynch Bridge was said to be the first suspension bridge in Britain, being built in 1741, for use by lead-miners, wishing to cross between Holwick and Bowlees.

places.name: Durham, England
places.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.

places.name: Middleton-in-Teesdale
places.description: Middleton-in-Teesdale is a market town and civil parish in County Durham, England. It is in Teesdale, on the River Tees's north banks, and surrounded by the North Pennines. The town is between Eggleston and Newbiggin, a few miles to the north-west of Barnard Castle.

places.name: Egglestone Hall
places.description: William Hutchinson (1763-1826) built Eggleston Hall in Teesdale County Durham in about 1817

places.name: River Tees
places.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.

places.name: Siccar Point
places.description: a rocky promontory in the county of Berwickshire on the east coast of Scotland. It is famous in the history of geology for Hutton's Unconformity found in 1788, which James Hutton regarded as conclusive proof of his uniformitarian theory of geological development.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

places.name: Berwickshire
places.description: a historic county in south-eastern Scotland, on the English border

places.name: Dunglass
places.description: a hamlet in East Lothian, Scotland, and the birthplace of Sir James Hall, geologist and geophysicist.

places.name: Siccar Point
places.description: a rocky promontory in the county of Berwickshire on the east coast of Scotland. It is famous in the history of geology for Hutton's Unconformity found in 1788, which James Hutton regarded as conclusive proof of his uniformitarian theory of geological development.

places.name: Whiteadder Water
places.description: a river in East Lothian and Berwickshire, Scotland. It flows for a very short distance through Northumberland before joining the River Tweed.

places.name: Haddington
places.description: The Royal Burgh of Haddington is a town in East Lothian, Scotland. It is the main administrative, cultural and geographical centre for East Lothian. It lies about 17 miles east of Edinburgh.

places.name: Haddington
places.description: The Royal Burgh of Haddington is a town in East Lothian, Scotland. It is the main administrative, cultural and geographical centre for East Lothian. It lies about 17 miles east of Edinburgh.

places.name: Oban
places.description: a resort town within the Argyll and Bute council area of Scotland.

places.name: Crianlarich
places.description: Crianlarich is a village in Stirling council area and in the registration county of Perthshire, Scotland, around 6 miles north-east of the head of Loch Lomond. The village bills itself as "the gateway to the Highlands".

places.name: Loch Earn
places.description: Loch Earn is a freshwater loch in the southern highlands of Scotland, in the districts of Perth and Kinross and Stirling.

places.name: Callander
places.description: a small town in the council area of Stirling, Scotland, situated on the River Teith.

places.name: Staffa
places.description: an island of the Inner Hebrides in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

places.name: Loch Katrine
places.description: Loch Katrine is a freshwater loch in the Trossachs area of the Scottish Highlands, east of Loch Lomond, within the historic county and registration county of Perthshire and the contemporary district of Stirling. The loch is about 8 miles long and 1 mile wide at its widest point, and runs the length of Strath Gartney.

places.name: Tyndrum
places.description: Tyndrum is a small village in Scotland. Its Gaelic name translates as "the house on the ridge". It lies in Strath Fillan, at the southern edge of Rannoch Moor.

places.name: Oban
places.description: a resort town within the Argyll and Bute council area of Scotland.

places.name: Loch Awe
places.description: A large body of freshwater in Argyll and Bute, Scottish Highlands.

places.name: Mull
places.description: The Isle of Mull is the second-largest island of the Inner Hebrides (after Skye) and lies off the west coast of Scotland.

places.name: Luss
places.description: Luss is a village in Argyll and Bute, Scotland, on the west bank of Loch Lomond. The village is within the Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park.

places.name: The Cobbler
places.description: The Cobbler is an 884 metres mountain located near the head of Loch Long in Argyll and Bute, Scotland. It is a Corbett, and is an important site for rock climbing in the Southern Highlands. Many maps include the name Ben Arthur, but the name The Cobbler is more widely used.

places.name: Edinburgh
places.description: The capital city of Scotland.

places.name: Loch Awe
places.description: A large body of freshwater in Argyll and Bute, Scottish Highlands.

places.name: Arrochar
places.description: Arrochar is a village located near the head of Loch Long, on the Cowal Peninsula, in Argyll and Bute, Scottish Highlands. The Arrochar Alps are named after the village.

places.name: Glasgow
places.description: Glasgow is a port city on the River Clyde in Scotland's western Lowlands.

places.name: The Rest and be Thankful
places.description: The Rest and be Thankful is a stunning mountain pass viewpoint which divides Glen Kinglas from Glen Croe. It gets its name as it was once a place where people travelling the country would stop, rest and be thankful that they have reached the top of their climb. It's a very popular viewpoint which follows the line of the old military road built in 1753 by General Wade and his soldiers.

places.name: Ben Lomond
places.description: Ben Lomond, 974 metres, is a mountain in the Scottish Highlands. Situated on the eastern shore of Loch Lomond, it is the most southerly of the Munros.

persons.name: JohnPlayfair
persons.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

places.name: Arthur's Seat
places.description: an ancient volcano which is the main peak of the group of hills in Edinburgh, Scotland, which form most of Holyrood Park

places.name: Edinburgh
places.description: The capital city of Scotland.

places.name: Salisbury Crags
places.description: a series of 46-metre (151 ft) cliffs at the top of a subsidiary spur of Arthur's Seat which rise on the west of Holyrood Park.

places.name: Yorkshire
places.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

places.name: Westmorland
places.description: Westmoreland is a historic county in north-west England spanning the southern Lake District and northern Dales.

places.name: Cumberland
places.description: Cumberland is a historic county in the far north-west of England.

places.name: Kings House Inn
places.description: The original Kings House, said to be one of Scotland's oldest licensed inns, was built in the 18th century. It was sited at the head of Glen Coe for travellers crossing Rannoch Moor. The Kings House Hotel is a remote inn at the eastern end of Glen Coe in the Scottish Highlands. The inn, which is in an isolated position about 2 km east of Glen Etive, stands on the edge of Rannoch Moor.

places.name: The White Mountain
places.description: Possibly: Casnip (known in English as the White Mountain) a mountain in the far north west of Scotland.  It is part of the Moine Thrust Belt and is typical of many of the Assynt hills in that it rises from a base of Lewisian Gneiss and is composed of Torridonian sandstone capped by Cambrian quartzite giving the hill a distinctive light grey crown. Its geology seems to match the description given by Davy, although it is some distance from the other locations he is discussing.

places.name: Mull
places.description: The Isle of Mull is the second-largest island of the Inner Hebrides (after Skye) and lies off the west coast of Scotland.

places.name: Ben Nevis
places.description: the highest mountain in Scotland, the United Kingdom and the British Isles.

places.name: 46 Devonshire Street, London
places.description: The registered address of two subscribers to the Royal Institution, Miss Slater and Mrs S Turner.

It was sited at the head of Glen Coe for travellers crossing Rannoch Moor. The Kings House Hotel is a remote inn at the eastern end of Glen Coe in the Scottish Highlands. The inn, which is in an isolated position about 2 km east of Glen Etive, stands on the edge of Rannoch Moor.

places.name: Strontian
places.description: The main village in Sunart, an area in western Lochaber, in the Highlands of Scotland. It was where the mineral strontianite was discovered, and from which the element strontium was first isolated.

places.name: Mull
places.description: The Isle of Mull is the second-largest island of the Inner Hebrides (after Skye) and lies off the west coast of Scotland.

places.name: Ulva
places.description: Ulva is a small island in the Inner Hebrides of Scotland, off the west coast of Mull. It is separated from Mull by a narrow strait, and connected to the neighbouring island of Gometra by a bridge. Much of the island is formed from Cenozoic basalt rocks, which are formed into columns in places.

places.name: Strontian
places.description: The main village in Sunart, an area in western Lochaber, in the Highlands of Scotland. It was where the mineral strontianite was discovered, and from which the element strontium was first isolated.

places.name: Loch Sunart
places.description: Loch Sunart is a sea loch on the west coast of Scotland. Loch Sunart is bounded to the north by the Sunart district of Ardnamurchan and to the south by the Morvern district. At 31 kilometres long, it is the longest sea loch in the Highland local government area.

places.name: Strontian
places.description: The main village in Sunart, an area in western Lochaber, in the Highlands of Scotland. It was where the mineral strontianite was discovered, and from which the element strontium was first isolated.

places.name: Glasgow
places.description: Glasgow is a port city on the River Clyde in Scotland's western Lowlands.

places.description: the highest mountain in Scotland, the United Kingdom and the British Isles.

places.name: River Aw
places.description: The River Awe is a short river in the south-west Highlands of Scotland.

places.name: Dumbarton
places.description: a town in West Dunbartonshire, Scotland, on the north bank of the River Clyde where the River Leven flows into the Clyde estuary.

places.description: an island in the Inner Hebrides, off the Ross of Mull on the western coast of Scotland.

places.name: Ben Cruachan
places.description: Ben Cruachan is a mountain that rises to 1,126 metres (3,694 ft), the highest in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

places.name: Lismore
places.description: Lismore is an island of some 2,351 hectares in the Inner Hebrides of Scotland. The climate is damp and mild, with over 166 centimetres of rain recorded annually.

places.name: Sound of Mull
places.description: The Sound of Mull is a sound between the Inner Hebridean island of Mull and mainland Scotland. It forms part of the Atlantic Ocean.

places.name: Oban

places.name: Maiden Island
places.description: Maiden Island is a small uninhabited island at the mouth of Oban Bay on the west coast of Scotland.

places.name: Oban
places.description: a resort town within the Argyll and Bute council area of Scotland.

places.name: Covent Garden
places.description: Covent Garden is a district in London, on the eastern fringes of the West End, between St Martin's Lane and Drury Lane. It is associated with the former fruit-and-vegetable market in the central square (now a popular shopping and tourist site), and with the Royal Opera House, itself known as "Covent Garden". By the 18th century it had become notorious for its abundance of brothels
